content.title: Xian, the rooftop you should not miss in Rio

introduction.small: In itself, Xian's spectacular panorama is worth the price of admission. The bar is also quite popular for its creative cocktails and lounge atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Xian, the rooftop you should not miss in Rio

paragraphs.text:
From the rooftop, Xian makes Cariocas and tourists see eye to eye. The unobstructed views over Guanabara Bay, Sugarloaf Mountain and Cristo Redentor make the bar an ideal location to gaze at the city, day and night, and a cocktail in hand. Behind the large marble counter, Rod Werner makes a display of his talents. The mixologist and his team prepare creative and surprising drinks, in a large number of combinations. Here, mixing styles is permitted and encouraged: beer-based cocktail, whisky sour, Spritz revisited using vodka… Let these subtle flavours amaze your senses – in moderation obviously – while you lounge on purple red bench seats under the sun porch. For a full nighttime experience, the lounge turns into a trendy nightclub where you can dance till daybreak, when sunrise will reveal an exceptional panorama again.

Xian
Rua Almirante Silvio de Noronha, 365 - Rooftop – Centro
Rio de Janeiro 20021-010

+55 (0)21 23 03 70 80

www.xianrio.com.br

Menu: cocktails from 27 BRL

content.title: Learn how to dance the samba like a real Carioca

introduction.small: Take advantage of being in Rio to learn the samba, a dance that is part of Brazil's cultural heritage

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Learn how to dance the samba like a real Carioca

paragraphs.text:
For men and women around the world, samba is one of the strongest symbols of Brasilian culture, especially during Rio's famous carnival. A fully developed dance that requires every part of the body, it is taught from an early age among Cariocas. In the city, Casa de Dança – Carlinhos de Jesus is considered as one of the best, teaching “samba no pé” (solo dancing) as well as “samba de gafieira” (as a couple). Make sure to practice a few words in Portuguese beforehand, as lessons take place in local idioms. For English teaching, head to the Rio Samba Dancer, specialized in teaching passing visitors. After some basic training, your teacher for a night will take you to Lapa, Rio's bohemian neighbourhood, where samba is danced in clubs and sometimes even right on the street. A perfect opportunity to practice and fully integrate local culture.

Casa de Dança – Carlinhos de Jesus
Rua Álvaro Ramos, 11
Botafogo
Rio de Janeiro 22280-110
+55 (0)21 2541 6186
www.casadedanca.com

Rio Samba Dancer
R. Francisco Otaviano, 61
Copacabana
Rio de Janeiro 22040-080
Tel : +55 (0)21 98229 2843
www.riosambadancer.com

content.title: Nosso, just like home

introduction.small: In Rio's Ipanema, Nosso is an alternative and informal hangout where you are strongly invited to make yourself at home

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nosso, just like home

paragraphs.text:
Nosso means “our” in Portuguese. The word sets the tone for the restaurant, located in Ipanema, with a warm welcome and a golden rule proudly exhibited: “here, make yourself at home”. In a large house that faces the Nossa Senhora da Paz Square, Nosso stands out in the neighbourhood with a facade made of glass. On the first floor, the high ceilings and retro-chic decoration shelter an arty-looking gastro-bar that offers a wonderful cocktail selection, all named after party characters (the host, the stranger…), rum being the main ingredient. The restaurant itself is located on the second floor, offering an abundance of bistronomic and creative dishes to choose from. For subtle discoveries, indulge in a ceviche served with leche de tigre marinade, quinoa and mango sorbet, or a 63°C egg with an arracacha mousseline, mushrooms and white truffle oil. Bring your evening to a new high on the last floor, where the rooftop gives you access to incredible views of Ipanema.

Nosso
Rua Maria Quitéria, 91
Ipanema
Rio de Janeiro 22410-040

+55 (0)21 99619 0099

www.nossoipanema.com

Menu: around 80 BRL

content.title: Yoo2 Rio, spectacular design and views

introduction.small: On the Guanabara Bay in Rio, Yoo2 offers you to stay among Brazil's most celebrated monuments.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Yoo2 Rio, spectacular design and views

paragraphs.text:
Sugarloaf Mountain on one side, the Corcovado and Cristo Redentor on the other… and then the ocean. In just one glance, Yoo2 Rio's rooftop reveals all the beauty the Brasilian megalopolis has to offer. In the lively Botafogo neighbourhood – nicknamed “Botasoho” due to its food and cultural scenes – the recent establishment is already a must-go-to on the Guanabara Bay. Over 12 floors, each of the 131 rooms unveil unobstructed views over Brasilian monuments. Scattered with local touches, the modern and stylish interior decoration showcases a tropical theme of Amazonian inspiration: the jungle takes over the rooms, up to the ceilings that are covered with gorgeous frescoes. Yoo2 Rio is the ideal pied-à-terre to visit the city, whether by yourself or during excursions organized by the hotel. Ride a bike for the street art guided tour or run in the early morning to discover Rio from down below.

Yoo2 Rio
Praia de Botafogo, 242
Botafogo
Rio de Janeiro 22250-040
Tel : +55 (0)21 34 45 20 00
yoo2.com/riodejaneiro

Rooms: from 285 BRL

content.title: Arty getaway at the 55 Rio Hotel

introduction.small: The 55 Rio Hotel has become a major player in the hospitality business of the Lapa neighbourhood, cultural and historical stronghold of the Cidade Maravilhosa, the “Marvellous City”.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Arty getaway at the 55 Rio Hotel

paragraphs.text:
Ideally nestled in the cultural centre of Brazil's largest city, the 55 Rio Hotel takes up the two most imposing historical mansions of the entire region. With distinct contemporary styles and a blend of bright colours, this establishment has managed a true and totally unique identity. Beyond the deliberately rural facade that has been entirely renovated, you will find 106 modern, luxurious and tastefully decorated bedrooms. Solid wood on the floors, geometrical patterns on the curtains and glass-made furniture give a sense of ease to the premises.
You will also be able to enjoy the rooftop and its unobstructed view over the Lapa Arches. Breakfast is additionally served there, with fresh products such as pastries, cheese, homemade jams, hand-pressed juices and seasonal fruit.
Do not hesitate to come back up anytime and use your camera, day and night, to snap the most unforgettable pictures!

Hotel 55 Rio
R. Visc. de Maranguape, 9
Centro, Rio de Janeiro
RJ, 20021-390

+55 21 3883-2030

www.55rio.com.br ﻿

Rooms: from 176 BRL

content.title: Lilia Restaurante, Rio's beautiful surprise

introduction.small: Only a few steps to walk up and there it is, Lilia or the carioca restaurant that will exalt your lunch.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lilia Restaurante, Rio's beautiful surprise

paragraphs.text:
In the very heart of Rio, this small restaurant displays modern and welcoming decoration amidst a traditional 19th-century house. Take the stairs that lead to it from the street and discover the family atmosphere that permeates the air: the two cousin owners named the restaurant after their grandmother Lilia as a tribute. With bricks, exposed beams, neon and suspended lights, this stripped-down charming atmosphere is sublimated by the warm rays of sun piercing through the large windows. Monday to Saturday and for lunch only, chef Lucio Vieira prepares contemporary homemade food that stands out with creative and flavourful seasonal products that have been carefully supplied by local agroforestry-supportive producers. His speciality: grilled food and the use of unconventional edible plants. The menu offers a unique selection with vegetarian alternative and changes every day, depending on deliveries. A perfect way to keep surprises going, with a timeless experience amid the carioca hustle and bustle!

Lilia
Rua do Senado, 45
Lapa
Rio de Janeiro 20231-000

+55 (0)21 3852 5423

www.facebook.com/lilia.restaurante/

Menu: around 52 BRL

content.title: Oteque, the ways and means of cooking quality products

introduction.small: Oteque serves a colourful and flavourful gastronomic cuisine in a good-natured atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Oteque, the ways and means of cooking quality products

paragraphs.text:
Ideally located between Botafogo and Lagoa, this small and intimate restaurant gives out a particularly warm atmosphere. The second you enter, you will feel at ease as everything was devised for your enjoyment and comfort. Wooden tables have been elegantly decorated and prettified by the use of stoneware dishes, amid a dining room showcasing exposed stone walls.
Lighting is perfectly subdued, as it should be. As for the decoration itself, its sober nature is perfectly in keeping with the local country style.
Each dish is a work of art and every meal is being prepared using only fresh and local products, supplied by environmentally-friendly farmers.
For instance, try the grilled octopus served with small tomatoes, oysters with coconut milk from Brazil or a deliciously tender duck breast fillet. For dessert, the pineapple sherbet is particularly sweet and goes together well with its accompanying biscuits. A perfectly sweet ending note for an outstanding meal.

Oteque
Rua Conde de Irajá, 581
Botafogo
Rio de Janeiro 22271-020

+55 (0)21 3486 5758

www.oteque.com

Menu: from 195 BRL

content.title: The Slow Bakery, carioca-style bread

introduction.small: Located right in Botafogo, the upper-middle-class district of Rio, this excellent Slow Food bakery delights with its delicious bread and coffee, a guaranteed organic treat!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Slow Bakery, carioca-style bread

paragraphs.text:
More than a bakery, The Slow Bakery claims, as its name implies, an art of living and return to essential values of life. Here, nothing is mass-produced: bread dough is made from the finest, carefully selected ingredients, before being patiently kneaded and baked in traditional ovens.
With their baguettes, loaves, sandwiches and toasts, Rafa and Lud, the two founders have managed to open this friendly and warm shop, thanks to crowdfunding, in the very lively district of Botafogo, a stone's throw from Copacabana Beach.
To accompany the different breads, including the famous Rio Sourdough or soft brioche, The Slow Bakery, which promotes quality craftsmanship and local development, offers a wide selection of coffees, as refined as its flour.

The Slow Bakery
Rua São João Batista, 93
Botafogo
Rio de Janeiro 22270-030

+55 (0)21 3563-8638

www.theslowbakery.com.br

Menu: 5 BRL for a focaccia

content.title: Emiliano Hotel, the jewel of Copacabana

introduction.small: Stylish, chic and cosy, the Emiliano has all the charm of a dream hotel with its infinity pool and views overlooking the legendary Copacabana Beach.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Emiliano Hotel, the jewel of Copacabana

paragraphs.text:
With its white perforated facade and plant wall, Emiliano Hotel provides a unique carioca experience. Located on the lively Copacabana Beach, its rooftop terrace with infinity pool overlooking the Pacific Ocean immediately sets the mood. The generous breakfasts are captivating, with a wide variety of dishes, especially when served in the wonderfully decorated spacious rooms. Special mention to the circular bathtub that looks out onto the waves. Take the time for a massage or treatment at the spa of over 1,100 sqm. Indulge in a delicious meal at the Emile restaurant, where French chef Damien Montecer offers modern Brazilian cuisine made from local organic products. On the rooftop, a champagne and caviar bar will satisfy your most prestigious desires, while being carried away by the bustling atmosphere of the surroundings.

Hotel Emiliano
Avenida Atlântica, 3804
Copacabana
Rio de Janeiro 22070-001

+55 (0)21 3503 6600

www.emiliano.com.br/en

Rooms: from 1,600 BRL

content.title: The Real Gabinete Português de Leitura Library, an architectural treasure

introduction.small: Considered one of the most beautiful libraries in the world, the Real Gabinete Português de Leitura is one of the essential places to visit in Rio de Janeiro.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Real Gabinete Português de Leitura Library, an architectural treasure

paragraphs.text:
In 1837, Portuguese immigrants from the city of Rio de Janeiro decided to build a library that resembled them. 50 years later, the Real Gabinete Português de Leitura (literally the “Portuguese Royal Reading Cabinet”) sees the light of day thanks to architect Rafael da Silva Castro. Considered one of the libraries with the largest and most prestigious collection of Portuguese literary works, it houses countless publications – over 350,000 –, on three floors.
Discover first editions, some dating back to the 16th century, as well as a small collection of paintings, sculptures and ancient coins. The decor is also worth seeing. The external Manueline-style facade in limestone imported from Lisbon, decorated with various statues, mixes Gothic and Moorish influences. The inside of the building is made of wood. Admire its coffered ceiling, carved columns and glass dome, letting in the perfect light for reading.

Real Gabinete Português de Leitura
Rua Luís de Camões 30
Rio de Janeiro 20051-020

+55 (0)21 2221 3138

www.realgabinete.com.br

content.title: A Sunday at Ipanema's hippie fair

introduction.small: This Sunday, at 7 in the morning, be the first to arrive at the hippie fair to do your shopping and find a few treasures.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A Sunday at Ipanema's hippie fair

paragraphs.text:
True cultural event, not far from Ipanema beach, the hippie fair's outdoor market will occupy your Sunday from 7am to 6pm. You will spend your day finding that rare gem, the souvenir that will bring the greatest joy to your loved ones. In addition to the many clothes and swimsuits snatched by all the tourists, enjoy the smaller artisanal crafts. The beautiful wood sculptures will catch your eye while you fall for the typically Brazilian multicoloured bracelets. Continue on your way towards the centre of the market to discover exquisite works representing Christ the Redeemer and the favelas. Throughout the period of the dictatorship (1964-1985) these artists had nowhere to exhibit. Hence, they set up the hippie fair on General Osório Square to reveal their most beautiful canvases.

Feira hippie
Plaça General Osorio
Ipanema
Rio de Janeiro 36950-000

www.feirahippieipanema.com

content.title: Football, the opium of the Brazilian people

introduction.small: More than a passion, football is a religion for many Brazilians. During your stay, enthusiastically immerse yourself in a “futebol” match.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Football, the opium of the Brazilian people

paragraphs.text:
The famous Maracanã Stadium may have lost its splendour since the last Summer Olympics, but the practice of football has continually livened up Rio's streets, fields and squares. Evidence of a truly popular passion, the list of registered teams in Brazilian cities continues to grow, giving rise to classicos, where there are overstimulated, sometimes rowdy environments.
Book your spot in one of the city's many stadiums: Maracanã, João-Havelange Olympic Stadium or São Januário. Admire the footwork of Luís Fabiano or Thalles among the camarotes (boxes) or mingle with the buzzing crowd on the side of the arquibancadas (bleachers of fans). Nevertheless, be sure to follow the frenzied movement of the stands you are now a part of: the more crucial the match, the more competition there is, giving rise to rivalry between fans of both teams. Ready to mingle with football fans?

Maracanã Stadium
Av. Pres. Castelo Branco, Portão 3
Maracanã
Rio de Janeiro 20271-130

João-Havelange Olympic Stadium
José dos Reis, 425
Engenho de Dentro
Rio de Janeiro 20770-001

São Januário Stadium
R. Gen. Almério de Moura, 131
Vasco da Gama
Rio de Janeiro 20921-060

www.futebolcard.com

content.title: Pabu Izakaya, a Japanese islet in Rio

introduction.small: A craving for sushi or ramen in the heart of Rio? Look no further, Pabu Izakaya will fulfil all your desires!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pabu Izakaya, a Japanese islet in Rio

paragraphs.text:
Located behind the famous Ipanema Beach in the trendy Leblon district, Pabu Izakaya is constantly full. This Brazilian "botequim" revisited with Japanese sauce offers dishes made from only the freshest ingredients.
Housed in a convivial space arranged like a horseshoe around a solid wood table, you will be spoilt for choice: the menu bounces between typical ramen (miso soups composed of noodles and meat or vegetables), gyoza (tender pork dumplings) and traditional chirashi and other raw fish. Special mention goes to the gunkan tuna and usuzukuri sea bass, as smooth as the famous grilled calamari with kimchi.
As for drinks, the menu focuses mainly on Japanese sake and distilled spirits, to enjoy with moderation. Ask for the servers' input, who will be happy to direct your choice. This beautiful canteen gives off Asian charm in a warm and cheerful atmosphere. You won't be able to resist!

Pabu Izakaya
Rua Humberto de Campos, 827
Loja G – Leblon
Rio de Janeiro 22430-190

+55 (0)21 3738 0416

www.facebook.com/pabuizakayario

Menu: from 16 BRL

content.title: Garoa Bar Lounge, hotspot for la festa carioca

introduction.small: In the trendy Leblon district, discover this cocktail bar and mingle with the Brazilian youth!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Garoa Bar Lounge, hotspot for la festa carioca

paragraphs.text:
Located just steps away from the legendary Ipanema Beach, Garoa Bar remains a hotspot for party-goers. Regulars of this warm atmosphere and passing visitors gather for drinks after work, spend a nice evening with friends and, of course, meet great people.
In an urban and trendy setting, expert barmen, under the guidance of their boss, the very outgoing Igor Renovato, concoct the best cocktails (now served with edible straws!): the most popular are the Black Label Whisky (smoked whisky, honey syrup with ginger and lemon) and the impossible to miss caïpirinhas, made with local cachaça.
Its very affordable prices and staff's cheerfulness make this bar a very popular place. As proof, its large windows are often left open to welcome those who rush to listen to the catchy programming of the best DJs. There is only one motto here, belonging to Igor: "Viva a festa!"

 

Garoa Bar Lounge
Rua Dias Ferreira, 50
Leblon
Rio de Janeiro 22431-050

+55 (0)21 3591 7617

www.facebook.com/garoarj/

Cocktails: from 32 BRL

content.title: In the cobbled cosiness of Rio de Janeiro

introduction.small: As Rio de Janeiro is not just about its carnival, we invite you to the heart of the urban jungle, all dressed in stone and glass. Let the exploration begin…

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: In the cobbled cosiness of Rio de Janeiro

paragraphs.text:
Rio's central district (Centro) has an abundance of historical buildings with astonishingly rich architecture. As you weave through bars crowded with regulars in full discussion, travellers, tourists and students cross paths in the endless bustle. Up ahead, “sobrados”, pastel-coloured colonial houses, resist developers with recent laws now protecting this heritage that makes up the charm of the historic district.
At nightfall, Centro is silent, under the benevolent gaze of the Nossa Senhora da Glória Baroque Church, a jewel of Brazilian religious colonial architecture.
From the Praça XV de novembro (November 15th Square), the residence of the governors of the city's captaincy in the 18th century, it was later home to the country's viceroys, John VI of Portugal, then Brazilian emperors.
Walking around Centro requires a certain sense of direction, yet allows you to discover a fascinating life, far from the common seaside images of Rio.

Rio de Janeiro's historic centre (Centro)

content.title: A love of Stuzzi

introduction.small: On Dias Ferreira Street, Stuzzi offers tasty culinary surprises in a cosy atmosphere. Follow the guide!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A love of Stuzzi

paragraphs.text:
Starting at 7 p.m., enjoy this luxurious establishment with its soft lighting and intimate atmosphere. On the south coast of Rio de Janeiro, the Stuzzi invites you to a table for a delicious dinner or cocktails that are expertly mixed. At the heart of the city's gastronomic district, red seating and wooden chairs gracefully complete each other in a space structured by a long bar.

Designed by the architect Bel Lobo, the restaurant shows an appreciable originality: bottles of alcohol are hung from the ceiling like lamps and sofas encourage you to relax. Opened in 2011, restaurant clients delight in the gourmet talents of chef Paula Prandini, represented with humour by Mona Lisa wearing a chef's hat and a kitchen jacket embroidered with the word “Stuzzi”. At night, wines, champagnes, sparkling wines and signature cocktails await you. Unless you would prefer a small “Zafferano”?

Stuzzi Bar
Rua Dias Ferreira, 48
22431-050 Leblon Rio de Janeiro – RJ

+55 (0)21 2274 4017

www.facebook.com/stuzzigastrobar/

Menu: around 120 BRL

content.title: Zuka: contemporary gastronomy

introduction.small: Make the most of a succulent meal prepared on the grill in a warm atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Zuka: contemporary gastronomy

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of the famous, fashionable district of Leblon, Zuka restaurant awaits you, a renowned establishment with innovative cuisine. Considered one of the best restaurants in the region, Zuka combines all the know-how of traditional churrasco (a barbecue over hot coals) with modern cuisine techniques, all in a carefully designed setting.

In his open kitchen, the chef prepares one of his specialties on the grill. A pure joy to see him in action! Try the tuna tartare with its avocado and wasabi mayonnaise before enjoying a honey-glazed duck breast with Moroccan couscous or a sumptuous grilled fish of the day with truffle sauce. For dessert, choose the brigadeiros, the typical Brazilian specialty, or tapioca ice cream with coconut sweets. Healthy and creative cuisine, just waiting to be tasted!

Zuka
Rua Dias Ferreira, 233B
Leblon
Rio de Janeiro 22431-050

+55 (0)21 3205 7154

www.zuka.com.br

Menu: around 70 BRL

content.title: A colourful ambiance at Zazá Bistrô Tropical

introduction.small: A perfect combination of Thai and Brazilian flavours will appeal to fusion cuisine lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A colourful ambiance at Zazá Bistrô Tropical

paragraphs.text:
Inside a typical old house, the Zazá Bistrô Tropical became one of the first contemporary restaurants of the city a few years ago. With its huge blue façade and Art Deco decoration, you will discover an original place with a cosy atmosphere. The chef, who draws inspiration from his travels around the world, is constantly on the lookout for new scents and savours to innovate and sublimate his cuisine.

His dishes with Asian touches are perfectly prepared and exclusively use organic ingredients. On the menu, you have the choice between chicken curry with vegetables, coconut milk and bananas served with jasmine rice, apricots and almonds, or the vegetarian lasagna with palm hearts, zucchini and eggplant coated with aged tomato sauce and orange. For dessert, choose the brigadeiro, a banana carpaccio, with a brownie and fruit salad. A real treat!

Zazá Bistrô Tropical
Rua Joana Angélica, 40
Ipanema
Rio de Janeiro 22420-030

+55 (0)21 2247 9101

www.zazabistro.com.br/zazabistrotropical

Menu: around 120 BRL

content.title: Sushi Leblon, one of the best sushi spots in Rio de Janeiro

introduction.small: Taste the chef's surprising culinary creations in one of Rio's trendiest Japanese restaurants.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sushi Leblon, one of the best sushi spots in Rio de Janeiro

paragraphs.text:
Considered one of the best Japanese restaurants in Rio, Sushi Leblon invites you to an elegant and refined setting. In the very heart of the trendy Leblon district, take a seat around the beautiful wooden counter that surrounds the kitchen of the restaurant and let yourself be transported by its zen and cosy atmosphere.

If you are a fish lover, you will be in seventh heaven! Start your ascent with a delicious bowl of edamame accompanied by a lychee caipisake, which is an original version of a caipirinha made with sake. Then choose from the wide variety of sashimi and expertly prepared sushi, or opt for the seared tuna recipe with foie gras and wasabi. Other culinary specialties are made with sea urchins, eel, and grilled squid, all of which are delicious. Note that Sushi Leblon was the first restaurant in Rio de Janeiro to experiment with Japanese and Western fusion cuisine.

Sushi Leblon
Rua Dias Ferreira, 256
Leblon
Rio de Janeiro 22431-05

+55 (0)21 2512 7830

www.sushileblon.com

Menu: around 60 BRL

content.title: Mirante Da Prainha – Restaurant on the water

introduction.small: The Mirante Da Prainha is a secret place without walls or a roof; a simple beach restaurant set on the beach of Prainha, with very tasty food.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mirante Da Prainha – Restaurant on the water

paragraphs.text:
The place is well known by surfers for its waves, but little frequented by tourists who prefer to linger on the nearby beaches of downtown Rio. The small restaurant is located right at the edge of the beach, the tables set in the sand with no fuss, and simply covered with red and white chequered tablecloths. The specialty here is grilled fish, prepared on the red brick barbecue installed a little away from the seafront, but be warned, the dishes are prepared according to the catch of the day, so it is better to arrive early. Besides the fish, which is usually accompanied by rice, fries and a small fresh salad, you can taste the “pastel”, a typically Brazilian stuffed pastry topped with a choice of cheese or grilled shrimp. Everything is delicious, the setting is superb, so get there as soon as you can.

Mirante da Prainha
Avenida Estado da Guanabara, 689
Recreio dos Bandeirantes,
Rio de Janeiro 22790-852

+55 (0)21 98014 9261

Menu: around 60 BRL

content.title: Bar Da Laje : dance the samba in Rio

introduction.small: Perched atop ‘Dois Irmãos' in the heart of Vidigal, a hip favela in Rio, the Bar Da Laje, facing the sea, welcomes residents and festive travellers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bar Da Laje : dance the samba in Rio

paragraphs.text:
Forget its troubled past, Vidigal, located between two ultra-chic neighbourhoods, Leblon and São Conrado, wants to improve its image. For ten years now, this ‘favela chic' has become arty, a witness to the cultural development of the city. Here and there you will find small art galleries and lounge bars, including the Bar da Laje. Located at the top of the hill, the bar is a favourite meeting place, with visitors and locals from 7 to 77 meeting there. Between two sambas, you can still enjoy Brazilian dishes. The specialty of the bar is its seafood, but it also offers feijoada, a pork-based dish with black beans, and you can eat on the go. Do not hesitate to ask for a cocktail, they are delicious, and then sit on the terrace, listen to the musicians and enjoy the view, which is probably one of the best in the world.

Bar Da Laje
Armando Almeida Lima, 8
Vidigal
22450-244 Rio de Janeiro

+55 21 3323 5807

http://bardalaje.rio/

Menu: around 20 BRL

content.title: Belmond Copacabana Palace: a myth in the heart of Rio

introduction.small: This palace of natural and authentic elegance, built during the Roaring Twenties, is a legend in Rio.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Belmond Copacabana Palace: a myth in the heart of Rio

paragraphs.text:
Designed by French architect Joseph Gire, who took inspiration from the palace hotels of the Côte d'Azur, this white neoclassical edifice on Atlântica Avenue and the beach of Copacabana, has been a Rio institution since 1923. Guests have included some of the most influential people in the world, including royals, politicians, singers, and movie stars. This reputation is due to the excellent service and the luxury of its 91 suites, 138 rooms and 7 penthouses which are divided between the main building and the wing built in 1948. Most have sea views. The rooms are styled in a contemporary manner and come equipped with spacious bathrooms, enamelled porcelain bathtubs, and marble-lined sinks. The lobby and pool are equally impressive, as are the three restaurants – the Pérgula, for brunch, the Cipriani for Italian cuisine, and the most recent, Mee, whose Asian menu has been awarded a Michelin star. The spa on two levels, tennis courts on the roof, beauty salon, and a host of other services add to the unforgettable character of the place.

Belmond Copacabana Palace
Avenida Atlântica 1702
Copacabana
Rio de Janeiro 22021-001

+55 (0)21 2548 7070

www.belmond.com

Rooms: from 1,350 BRL

content.title: Casa Amarelo: a villa decorated by Robert le héros

introduction.small: Another fabulous address in the Santa Teresa neighbourhood, successfully combining tradition, modernity, and design.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Casa Amarelo: a villa decorated by Robert le héros

paragraphs.text:
It's impossible to miss this villa and its tower, whose yellow facade brightens the whole neighbourhood of Santa Teresa. Built in 1904, the listed building, in bourgeois-manor style, is now owned by Laurent Gelis, head of the graphics and design agency that creates Robert le héros fashion accessories, fabrics, arts of the table, and cushions. The seven spacious rooms at Casa Amarelo are playful and colourful, with high ceilings and a French-Brazilian design sensibility that blends classic and contemporary. There are floral patterns in some rooms, yellow and red colours in others. The impression is always fresh and invigorating. Of special note is the 40-square-metre Blossom Suite in pastel pink with large bathroom and huge shower. The highlight is the pool and the winter garden, which offer breath-taking views of the Catedral Metropolitana de São Sebastião.

Casa Amarelo
Rua Joaquim Murtinho, 569
Santa Teresa
Rio de Janeiro 20241-320

+55 (0)21 3549 9840

www.casa-amarelo.com/en

Rooms: from 250 BRL

content.title: Jardim Botânico: an extraordinary garden

introduction.small: An ecological oasis in the heart of Rio, ideal for relaxing amid a dizzying array of flora varieties.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jardim Botânico: an extraordinary garden

paragraphs.text:
Welcome to the tropics. Hidden from the crowds, the Botanical Garden stretches over 140 hectares and contains more than 6,000 varieties of plants as wells as an array of extraordinary animal species, including toucans, parrots, and marmosets. A jungle in the city, designed in a neoclassical style, amid aristocratic and romantic architecture, the garden once belonged to the King John VI of Portugal and the royal family, exiled to Rio in the early 19th century.

The paths are lined with imperial palms, tropical trees with giant trunks, and, in the corners of the garden, there are sensational cactus and orchid collections. The views are stunning, with Corcovado in the distance, and the gazebos and greenhouses alone are worth the visit. Here and there, porticos and fountains bring an extra poetic touch. Today it is a protected garden, as the city of Rio and all its treasures have been listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 2012.

Jardim Botânico
Rua Jardim Botânico, 1008
Rio de Janeiro 22460-030

+55 (0)21 3874 1808

www.jbrj.gov.br/

content.title: Mama Ruisa: the charm of colonial style

introduction.small: A guesthouse of rare elegance, in the picturesque hills of Santa Teresa.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mama Ruisa: the charm of colonial style

paragraphs.text:
Hidden in the winding streets of Santa Teresa, this old colonial house was beautifully restored by the French owner Jean-Michel Ruis in 2005.

A guesthouse with the air of a boutique hotel, it enjoys an extraordinary calm, surrounded by flowers and palm trees. Along with very personalized service, the Mama Ruisa offers exotic Brazilian decor, tinged with French sophistication. A precious collection of objects, religious trinkets, and rare sculptures from the provinces of Brazil and elsewhere in the world are on display in the gallery. The eight sublime rooms have been designed according to different themes and personalities, ranging from Art Deco to Jean Cocteau to the Brazilian singer Carmen Miranda. Everywhere, the antique furniture, antique wood floors, high ceilings and shuttered windows bring a chic and romantic touch. The communal lounges with jacaranda wood sofas by Ricardo Fasanello and Sérgio Rodrigues, overlook a veranda with views of Sugarloaf Mountain.

The sunken pool is an intimate paradise where you will love relaxing. Another highlight is the new house containing a few suites, just in front of Mama Ruisa.

Mama Ruisa
Rua Santa Cristina, 132
Santa Teresa
Rio de Janeiro 20241-250

+55 (0)21 2210 0631

www.mamaruisa.com

Rooms: from 800 BRL

content.title: Parque Lage: a luxurious walk

introduction.small: A colonial café in the heart of the rainforest, offering a tranquil and beautiful interlude.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Parque Lage: a luxurious walk

paragraphs.text:
An alternative to the Jardim Botânico, this smaller public park, housed at the foot of Corcovado, is one of the most beautiful in the city.

The main attraction is the beautiful colonial mansion and former home of wealthy industrialist Enrique Lage and his wife, the famous singer Gabriella Besanzoni. Renovated in the 1920s by the Italian architect Mario Vodrel, it is now occupied by the School of Visual Arts of Parque Lage and its café and restaurant. In these quiet surroundings, regulars, families, and curious tourists come for a fresh-air stroll in the residence's English gardens. Snap a few shots in front of the superb swimming pool, admire the view of Christ the Redeemer in the distance, and amuse yourself on the park's little bridges, at the aquarium, or among the monkeys that live here year-round.

Statues also dot the park, including that of Tom Jobim, one of the fathers of Brazilian bossa nova.

Parque Lage
Rua Jardim Botânico, 414
Jardim Botânico
Rio de Janeiro 22461-000

+55 (0)21 3257 1800

www.eavparquelage.rj.gov.br

content.title: Theatro Municipal: a temple of culture and music

introduction.small: Featuring glitzy ‘Parisian' decor, this building hosts Rio's best ballets and concerts.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Theatro Municipal: a temple of culture and music

paragraphs.text:
With its majestic facade and large columns and sculptures at the entrance, the Theatro Municipal in Rio is one of the key monuments of the Centro neighbourhood. Opened July 14, 1909, the building, whose architecture was largely inspired by the Opera Garnier in Paris, has nearly 2,300 seats and specializes in opera, ballet, jazz, and bossa nova concerts.

The facade is indeed impressive, but no more so than the charming interior: the gorgeous decor by Eliseu Visconti, Rodolfo Amoedo, and artist Henrique Bernardelli has long attracted artists and personalities from around the world. Dark wood, Carrara marble, paintings, bronzes, mirrors, and onyx the place delights during a performance, or a guided tour.

Continue on to the municipal library, the National Museum of Fine Arts, and the Palace Pedro Ernesto, less touristic sights that are all absolute charming.

Theatro Municipal

Praça Marechal-Floriano
Centro
Rio de Janeiro 20031-050

+55 (0)21 2332 9191

www.theatromunicipal.rj.gov.br/

content.title: Aprazível : a room with a view

introduction.small: In the hills of Santa Teresa, an earthly paradise with authentic Brazilian cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Aprazível : a room with a view

paragraphs.text:
The Santa Teresa neighbourhood hides a gem. There, on a rural terrace in the hills of Rio, Cariocas and tourists come to contemplate the sunsets and the incredible views of Guanabara Bay.

This charming cabana, with its mango trees and straw umbrellas around old farm tables, serves traditional Brazilian cuisine by Chef Ana Castilho. The nostalgic family dishes, influenced by the region of Minas Gerais in the heart of Brazil, renowned for its fine cuisine include the polenta snacks originally cooked by slave women on coffee farms; Carioca rice balls with coconut; grilled shrimp with saffron rice; and freshly caught fish every night (freshwater catches with coriander or tropical fish with orange sauce).

The selection of wines is extensive and includes those classified as “natural”.

Aprazível
Rua Aprazível, 62
Santa Teresa
Rio de Janeiro 20241-270

+55 (0)21 2508 9174

www.aprazivel.com.br

Menu: around 150 BRL

content.title: Hotel Santa Teresa: a refuge for celebrities

introduction.small: Perched in the hills of the same neighbourhood, a discreet hotel serves as a rendezvous point for celebrities in search of romance.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Santa Teresa: a refuge for celebrities

paragraphs.text:
The Santa Teresa's five stars shine on the hills of the district of the same name. Originally an old colonial building on a former coffee plantation, the hotel has regained its lustre thanks to François Delort, who has turned it into a luxury hotel. After four years of work, its 44 elegant suites and rooms combine Brazilian culture and materials (wood and recycled jacaranda) with objects, fabrics, and antique sculptures. Since its opening, many celebrities have stayed here, including Madonna, Amy Winehouse, and Alicia Keys, all of whom stayed in the largest suite-160 square metres-which comes with a telescope for star-gazing. Other areas of the hotel are just as appealing, including the pool and its breath-taking view of the city and the mountains of Teresopolis, the Champagne bar Descasados, the Térèze Restaurant, and a Spa that offers essential oil and natural product-based care.

Hotel Santa Teresa
Rua Almirante Alexandrino, 660
Santa Teresa
Rio de Janeiro 20240-260

+55 (0)21 3380 0200

www.santateresahotelrio.com

Rooms: from 752 BRL

content.title: Olympe : the ‘French touch'

introduction.small: Traditional French classics with Brazilian flourishes subtly prepared by a star chef.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Olympe : the ‘French touch'

paragraphs.text:
He is a superstar in Brazil. Brother of the multi-starred Michel Troisgros, Claude Troisgros is among the few French chefs to have made a successful go of it in Rio. Regularly named chef of the year and a star of television cooking shows, Troisgros arrived in Brazil more than 30 years ago, and now heads a small empire. Olympe, which he runs with his son Thomas, is the most popular restaurant among gastronomes. His style: classic French cuisine sprinkled with Brazilian flavours, entirely based on fresh market produce. You can choose between a tasting menu, which gives carte blanche to the chef, or the traditional version, which features duck breast with roasted Chinese cabbage, sumac and black olives, or a sautéed slipper lobster with cardoncello mushrooms, asparagus and white wine foam. Desserts are equally delightful: chocolate and red fruits crumble, mango, mint and ginger meringue pie, as well as caramelised passion fruit pancakes all illustrate the chef's fusion spirit.

Olympe
Rua Custódio Serrão, 62
Jardim Botânico
Lagoa
Rio de Janeiro 22470-230

+55 (0)21 2537 8582

http://olympe.com.br/en/

Menu: from 250 BRL

content.title: Museu do Amanhã: a museum dedicated to ideas

introduction.small: Under its futuristic skeleton, the new Rio museum offers a reflection on the origins and future of humanity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museu do Amanhã: a museum dedicated to ideas

paragraphs.text:
The Museu do Amanhã or ‘Museum of Tomorrow' opened in December 2015 in the old port district of Rio, now gentrified.

It looks like a gigantic dinosaur skeleton not out of prehistory, but from a science-fiction novel. The futuristic museum-vessel was designed by the Catalan architect Santiago Calatrava and was originally inspired by the tropical bromeliad plant. Dedicated to ideas rather than objects, the building mixes art and science, and asks questions about the origins of the planet and its future potential in terms of ecology and the environment. Designed as a cosmic portal, you enter the museum via the screening of a film about the evolution of geology. The three other spaces offer interactive facilities and performances about the flow of materials, human biology, and the nervous system.

The heart of the museum, filled with giant totems, draws our attention, through sight and sound, to the major issues of humanity.

Museu do Amanhã
Praça Mauá, 1
Centro
Rio de Janeiro 20081-240

+55 (0)21 3812 1800

www.museudoamanha.org.br

content.title: Restaurante Mee: gourmet Asian cuisine

introduction.small: An institution in Copacabana, where the flavours of Asia flirt with the peaks.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Restaurante Mee: gourmet Asian cuisine

paragraphs.text:
The restaurant in the Belmond Copacabana Palace, located just off the famous swimming pool, is among the first Latin American restaurants to have been awarded a Michelin star. It is also the first Pan-Asian luxury restaurant in the city. The decor is chic, with lovely banquettes and a gallery of portraits by the Belgian artist Christian Develter. Led by the BBC's cooking-show star Ken Hom, the kitchen mixes Thai, Cambodian, Malaysian, Singaporean, Korean, Vietnamese, Chinese, and Japanese influences. Besides the excellent sushi bar and sublime yellow-marble countertop, you come to Mee for Thai spicy salad with mandarin orange, an incredible selection of dim sum or the Shanghai braised pork belly. To accompany these dishes, order from one of 25 sakes imported from Japan, as advised by the only sake sommelier in the city.

Restaurante Mee
Copacabana Palace Hotel
Avenida Atlântica, 1702
Copacabana
Rio de Janeiro 22021-001

+55 (0)21 2548 7070

www.copacabanapalace.com.br

Menu: around 160 BRL

content.title: TuAkAzA: a wonder lodged in the heart of nature

introduction.small: Ideal for rest and meditation, this villa built on tree trunks offers sensational panoramic views.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: TuAkAzA: a wonder lodged in the heart of nature

paragraphs.text:
Just 10 minutes from Ipanema, this guesthouse is situated in the heart of Tijuca National Park, the largest urban forest in the world. A picturesque construction, all in wood, it was built in the 1960s by a big name in Brazilian architecture, José Zanine, and it took ten years to renovate. The new owner, Matteo Basadonna, revived this treasure, a villa of 10,000 square metres in a stunning landscape, overlooking the São Conrado beach and facing Pedra da Gávea mountain—a majestic and enigmatic rectangular stone slab that you can see from the six suites of the house. The rooms have exotic decor, wooden parquet ceilings, and rustic furniture that is carved and hand-painted in different shades of blue, violet, and black. To complete your stay, enjoy the rock swimming pool under the waterfall, the spa, and a wide range of activities, such as climbing, swimming, and paragliding.

TuAkAzA
Estrada das Canoas, 2600
São Conrado
Rio de Janeiro 22610-210

+55 (0)21 3322 6715

www.tuakaza.com

Rooms: from 880

BRL

content.title: Catedral Metropolitana de São Sebastião: Glass and light

introduction.small: The unusual and spectacular architecture of this cathedral hides a wonderful decor.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Catedral Metropolitana de São Sebastião: Glass and light

paragraphs.text:
Between Centro and the northeast corner of Lapa stands a most impressive monument the Cathedral of San Sebastian, the seat of the Archbishop of Rio de Janeiro and one of the largest Catholic buildings in the world.

Its avant-garde lines and Mayan temple look come from its daring creator, architect Edgar Oliveira da Fonseca, who, faced with the increasing urbanization of the city, imagined, in the late 1960s, a 96-metre-high pyramid capable of accommodating nearly 20,000 faithful. Built of poured concrete, the cathedral has four huge stained-glass windows that start at the ground and form a cross at the top. These incredible glass panels bathe the interior in a variety of dazzling colours and hues. At night, the spectacle seems almost supernatural.

After the visit, go see the Escadaria Selarón, the 215 famous steps covered with mosaics, or dip into the bustle of Lapa.

Catedral Metropolitana São Sebastião
Avenida Chile 245
Centro
Rio de Janeiro 20031-170

+55 (0)21 2240 2669

www.catedral.com.br

content.title: Arpoador: unbeatable sunsets

introduction.small: A picture-perfect paradise for surfers, lovers of nature, and Carioca youth.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Arpoador: unbeatable sunsets

paragraphs.text:
Between Ipanema and Copacabana, the residential area of Arpoador and its seafront and rocky promontory now attract tourists from around the world, who come to admire the sunsets.

In the late afternoon, after swimming, playing ball, and tanning, the bewitching show begins, with great views of the nearby beaches and Pedra da Gávea mountain on one side, and Praia do Diabo beach (recommended for sunrises) and Sugarloaf on the other. A surfer hangout for years, the Arpoador is a great place to take classes and improve your surfing.

The presence of a skate-park in Garota Park is another draw. After the beach, hit the district's many bars, cafes, and clubs.

hotelarpoador.com/en

content.title: Bazzar: contemporary cuisine in Ipanema

introduction.small: A stylish address, serving glorious fusion food.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bazzar: contemporary cuisine in Ipanema

paragraphs.text:
The place is worth a visit just for the decor: a wooden facade and a bamboo terrace and, behind the large windows, the bright interior of the restaurant, filled with long tables d'hôtes and a large counter. An avant-garde design for a fusion cuisine, where Brazilian dishes and European influences blend perfectly, all made from local products. Among the most successful dishes: spaghetti with fresh tomatoes and almonds; risotto with Grana Padano cheese; Moqueca fish dishes served on mashed bananas da terra (plantains) with coconut sauce and palm hearts. Like the rest of the food, the list of desserts verges on international flavours, and for a Brazilian touch, a stunning mango, orange and orange blossom mousse with a pinch of rapadura (unrefined whole cane sugar).

Bazzar
Rua Barão da Torre, 538
Ipanema
Rio de Janeiro 22411-002

+55 (0)21 3202 2884

www.bazzar.com.br

Menu: from 80 BRL

content.title: Julius Brasserie: culinary multiculturalism in Urca

introduction.small: At the foot of Sugarloaf Mountain, a charming brasserie with international influences.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Julius Brasserie: culinary multiculturalism in Urca

paragraphs.text:
Upon his arrival in Rio in 2010, the Dutch owner, Julius, fell in love with this charming and atypical restaurant in the village of Urca, a town of 7,000 inhabitants in the Rio's Zona Sul.

This brasserie, with large bay windows, offers a unique view, just below Sugarloaf Mountain. The picture-postcard scenery has long attracted Cariocas and couples looking for a romantic interlude. The menu brings together contemporary Brazilian, French, Italian and Dutch influences, from ceviche and steak tartare for starters, excellent meat selection (Black Angus beef, duck breast, Thai curry), various risottos, and the fresh fish of the day. The same spirit animates the dessert section, with the chocolate tart sure to win your vote.

The decoration will add to your delight: fluffy blue banquettes and chic tables.

Julius Brasserie
Avenida Portugal, 986
Urca
Rio de Janeiro 22291-050

+55 (0)21 3518 7117

www.juliusbrasserie.com.br

Menu: around 75 BRL

content.title: Floresta da Tijuca: a surprising artificial forest

introduction.small: This paradise delights hikers, tourists, and lovers of flora and fauna.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Floresta da Tijuca: a surprising artificial forest

paragraphs.text:
In the middle of Tijuca National Park which also includes Pedra da Gávea, Corcovado, and the statue of Christ the Redeemer the Tijuca forest contains more than 30 square kilometres of planted trees.

Razed to make way for coffee plantations, the original jungle was reforested in 1860 by order of Emperor Peter II. While most tourists come here by taxi, the forest has many great hiking and biking paths and trails. Excursions here will disconnect you from the permanent hubbub of the city and immerse you in lush vegetation, where you can observe at leisure a colourful range of wildlife insects, lizards, cobras, coatis, foxes, hawks, and primates.

A UNESCO World Heritage Site, the Tijuca Forest attracts more than 1.5 million nature lovers every year.

Floresta da Tijuca
Praça Afonso Viseu
Estrada do Alto
Rio de Janeiro

+55 (0)21 2491 1700

www.parquedatijuca.com.br

content.title: Arcos da Lapa and its stunning architecture

introduction.small: At the entrance to the Lapa district is the old monumental aqueduct in Rio, where the city tram now runs.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Arcos da Lapa and its stunning architecture

paragraphs.text:
It is a monument to the history of Rio. Built in 1723 in the district of Lapa, this ancient aqueduct in bright white carried spring water from the hills to the centre of the city. With the installation of water pipes, the place was refitted in the late 19th century as “Arcos da Lapa”, a series of arcades traversed by the bonde eléctrico, the tramway linking Lapa to the hills of Santa Teresa.

A great place to take photos from, and to see the Escadaria Selarón and its 215 steps in earthenware tiles. Or get lost in the streets of Centro, among its quaint markets (best at carnival and Christmas time). Then spend the evening in Lapa, one of the most nocturnal neighbourhoods in Rio, where samba bars abound, and young people and tourists come to hear rock, hip-hop, and more alternative music, like, perhaps, the Ramones.

Arcos da Lapa
Rua Riachuelo, 27
Rio de Janeiro 20231-040

content.title: Brigite's: for a trendy dinner in Leblon

introduction.small: A festive bistro with Mediterranean influences in the heart of the bustling Leblon neighbourhood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Brigite's: for a trendy dinner in Leblon

paragraphs.text:
Opened since 2012 on Rua Dias Ferreira, one of Rio's most gastronomic streets, Brigite's is the third restaurant owned by Ana Carolina Gayoso and Beatriz Stewart, already at the head of the famous Sushi Leblon and Zuka, both also in Leblon.

The address will seduce you with its deceptively colonial decor, white wooden floor, and large festive bar on the ground floor, which draws crowds from the early evening, as well as the much quieter loft upstairs. In the kitchen, Kiko Faria concocts a ‘bistronomic' menu a combination of bistro and gastronomy on a Mediterranean and Italian theme. Among the best dishes: the Namoradoem Crosta Marrone, an absolutely delicious cashew-crusted fish; traditional filet mignon with potatoes and asparagus; and for dessert, the chocolate soufflé.

The house is also famous for its cocktails by bartender Leonardo Pereira, aka ‘Black Leo'.

Brigite's
Rua Dias Ferreira, 247 a
Leblon
Rio de Janeiro 22431-050

+55 (0)21 2274 5590

www.brigites.com.br

Menu: around R$ 125

content.title: Cristo Redentor: a wonder of the world

introduction.small: Overlooking Rio, the giant statue of Christ the Redeemer reveals to all who visit him the most magical views of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cristo Redentor: a wonder of the world

paragraphs.text:
On top of the Corcovado Mountain stands one of the most famous statues in the world. Measuring 38 meters high and weighing nearly 1,200 tones, the work of French sculptor Paul Landowski is perched 700 meters above sea level.

To get there, there are several possibilities. The simplest way is to take the little red train, whose climb through the rainforest takes about 20 minutes. If you have time, stop at the Museu Internacional de Arte Naif (MIAN), the outsider-art museum, and at the colonial square in Largo do Boticário, both worth a visit. Other options are by car or on foot (count two and a half hours and several bottles of water) to a point of embarkation that will lead you to the top.

Once there, the Cristo Redentor rises before your eyes, and the great views of Rio's Maracanã stadium, Sugarloaf Mountain, the Jardim Botânico, Ipanema, and Leblon, make you quickly forget the trouble it took to get there.

Cristo Redentor
Parque Nacional da Tijuca
Alto da Boa Vista
Rio de Janeiro

+55 (0)21 2558 1329

www.corcovado.com.br

content.title: Suite by Dussol: escape into another world

introduction.small: A romantic retreat away from the bustle of Rio, for travellers in search of enchantment.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Suite by Dussol: escape into another world

paragraphs.text:
At the end of a winding road, a 15-minute walk from the Joating a beach, is this confidential boutique hotel where celebrities come to get away from it all. This is the second address, after the House by Dussol (Jardim Botânico), of François-Xavier Dussol, a French pioneer of boutique hotels in Rio.

Behind the red door of this 1960s villa, a huge terrace sets the tone: the ocean spreads out before your eyes and, in the distance, the statue of Christ the Redeemer towers above the Rocinha favela. The hotel offers seven suites with flamboyant decorations, in Baroque and Pop Art themes, alternating yellow, pink, and white monochrome tones... or you could try the all-glass ‘Black Suite'.

There are chandeliers everywhere, as well as kitsch Brazilian knickknacks and collectibles, and fabulous views. This endearing family home has an infinity pool lined up with the sea and a heliport on the roof, where you can also have dinner.

Suite by Dussol
Rua Jackson de Figueiredo, 501
Joá
Rio de Janeiro 22611-000

+55 (0)21 3259 6123

www.bydussol.com/la-suite

Rooms: from 750 BRL

content.title: Miam Miam: a festive canteen

introduction.small: Come here for picture-postcard decor in quiet Botafogo and creative Latin cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Miam Miam: a festive canteen

paragraphs.text:
Not as 'party-on' as Ipanema or Copacabana, Botafogo will charm you instead with its glorious views of Sugarloaf, its endless sailboats, museums, cafés, and art galleries. Established in 2005 by Roberta Ciasca (also head of Noddy in Humaitá), this restaurant has quickly become one of the hottest addresses in Rio. Main asset: its homey decor in chic retro, with brick walls and furniture from the 1950s to the 1970s. Its charm is irresistible. Besides its excellent caipirinhas, the Miam Miam has earned an enviable reputation for its creative Latino food. Highlights include the moqueca fish and shrimp stew in spicy curry, duck breasts, watercress risotto and apple purée. Order a tasting menu or a la carte in small portions. Simple and delicious.

Miam Miam
Rua General Góis Monteiro, 34
Botafogo
Rio de Janeiro 22290-080

+55 (0)21 2244 0125

www.miammiam.com.br

Menu: around 95 BRL

content.title: Hotel Fasano: the marriage of bossa nova and elegance

introduction.small: This five-star luxury hotel has all the necessary ingredients for a dream stay.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Fasano: the marriage of bossa nova and elegance

paragraphs.text:
Only opened in 2007, the Fasano Rio is already a legendary hotel, attracting stars and personalities from around the world. Facing the sea and overlooking the Ipanema beach, this is the second hotel of the Fasano family, who also has a splendid hotel in São Paulo.

The hotel's decor, by Philippe Starck, was inspired by bossa nova, and mixes materials and furniture from Brazilian craft culture with Greek marble and Argentine brick. On each of the seven floors, customers find the famous ‘Big Mama' armchairs of Italian Gaetano Pesce. The furniture in the rooms, which have panoramic views of the beaches, is by Sérgio Rodrigues and Starck. A stay at the Fasano requires you to do a small tour on the roof, where the bar and the huge infinity pool are located.

And don't forget the Al Mare, one of the most renowned Italian restaurants in Rio.

Hotel Fasano Rio de Janeiro
Avenida Vieira Souto, 80
Ipanema
Rio de Janeiro 22420-002

+55 (0)21 3202 4000

www.fasano.com.br

Rooms: from 2,740 BRL

content.title: Esquina 111 Rádio Bar: the bar of the moment in Rio

introduction.small: Don't overlook this new hot spot in Ipanema for sharing a bite and a glass on the terrace or inside.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Esquina 111 Rádio Bar: the bar of the moment in Rio

paragraphs.text:
A new and quiet address in the Ipanema district, this restaurant on the corner of Maria Quiteria and Redentor occupies an unusual house of industrial design, with a grey facade, yellow tints on the terrace, shutters, a brick bar, flowerpots on the window ledges, and a few palm trees.

The Brazilian touch is felt in the traditional furniture and the choice of patterns on the cushions and large colored benches. An urban oasis better suited for groups of friends than more private affairs, the bar serves small portions for sharing. Especially good are the mini cheeseburgers with two mustards and the cocktail menu, including the basil and ginger caipirinha, the house specialty.

Esquina 111 Rádio Bar
Rua Maria Quitéria, 111
Ipanema
Rio de Janeiro 22421-030

+55 (0)21 3256 9375

www.facebook.com/esquina111/

Menu: around R$ 75

content.title: Ipanema Beach: party in the sand!

introduction.small: A name that resonates around the world. Romantic sunsets, caipirinha competitions, ‘futevôlei' games this is the real Rio!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ipanema Beach: party in the sand!

paragraphs.text: Over more than three kilometres of fine sand, Ipanema Beach is even more famous than its neighbour Copacabana, thanks, of course, to its hit song, The Girl from Ipanema, and the fact that the cult of the body dominates there like nowhere else. This has always been true: the bronzed beauties of Rio's gilded youth, straight and gay, prefer this beach to all others. Favela kings hang out at Posto 8, surfers at Arpoador, and Ipanema gets crowded on weekends, with its volleyball and futevôlei (foot volleyball) matches. Best to get up early to enjoy the spectacle of the mountain view of Dois Irmãos—‘two brothers', because of its split peak. Later in the day, the spectacular sunsets are a knockout. Lounge chairs and parasols can be rented in the barraca of your choice, where you can order your água de coco, a caipirinha aperitif, mate, or globos—shrimp crisps that look (and taste) like Styrofoam...

content.title: Santa Teresa: Rio's bohemian spirit

introduction.small: Often compared to Paris' Montmartre or San Francisco, Santa Teresa is popular as much for its charming colonial houses as for the festive and artistic life that prevails there.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Santa Teresa: Rio's bohemian spirit

paragraphs.text:
Without doubt the most charming district of the city, Santa Teresa was built on the hills of the central part of Rio around a convent. In the 19th century it became known for its winding streets lined with castle-like colonial houses featuring quaint gardens. Some are foolhardy enough to attempt walking here, but most take the bonde eléctrico tram.

This is a neighbourhood to get lost in, and to then find refuge in one bar and then another, listening to jazz or bossa nova until the wee hours. Many festivals are also held here, and the Portas Abertas event in July, when artists open the doors of their studios, draws crowds. Nearby is the cultural centre of Parque das Ruínas, worth a look for its architecture, as is a visit to the former home of the Brazilian politician Benjamin Constant.

content.title: Copacabana Fort: unusual vestige of Brazilian history

introduction.small: A fort's ancient bunker now offers cultural activities and magical views.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Copacabana Fort: unusual vestige of Brazilian history

paragraphs.text:
Facing the Guanabara Bay, this bunker-like fortress offers an unusual perspective on the beaches of Copacabana, Sugarloaf, and the Arpoador neighbourhood.

Built in the early 20th century, the fortress protects the southern zone of Rio and was the scene of many violent episodes, including the famous '18 of the Copacabana Fort revolt'. The guns, still visible on the roof, are plugged now: the fort was demilitarized in the 1980s, opened to the public, and turned into a place of tourism and culture. Visits to the bunker are still possible, as are visits to the Army Museum, admittedly minimalist, and the art gallery, the theatre, and the two restaurants.

For the 2016 Olympics, the bunker hosted the marathon and triathlon events.

For the 2016 Olympics, the bunker will host the marathon and triathlon events.

Copacabana Fort
Praça Coronel Eugênio Franco, 1
Copacabana
Rio de Janeiro 22070-020

+55 (0)21 2521 1032

www.fortedecopacabana.com

content.title: Niterói Contemporary Art Museum: Brazilian art today

introduction.small: Oscar Niemeyer's stunning architectural work celebrated its 20th anniversary in 2016.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Niterói Contemporary Art Museum: Brazilian art today

paragraphs.text:
Facing Rio, in the ancient capital of the State of Rio de Janeiro, which you can access by boat, Niterói is a museum in uplifting architecture. Like a flying saucer, the Museum of Contemporary Art (MAC) by the Brazilian architect Oscar Niemeyer - with the help of structural engineer Bruno Contarini - is a white concrete dome 16 metres high and 50 metres in diameter, divided into two large exhibition areas. A futuristic structure opened in 1996, it houses collections of the most influential Brazilian artists, but also puts on performances and happenings by contemporary artists. Closed for renovation in 2015, the museum reopened with new facilities in 2016 on the occasion of its 20th anniversary. Don't miss the viewing gallery, from which the vistas of Guanabara Bay, Rio de Janeiro, and Sugarloaf Mountain are breathtaking.

Niterói Museu de Arte Contemporânea
Mirante da Boa Viagem
Boa Viagem
Niterói
Rio de Janeiro 24210-390

+55 (0)21 2620 2400

www.culturaniteroi.com.br/macniteroi

content.title: The public art of Escadaria Selarón

introduction.small: The Selarón Steps in the Lapa and Santa Teresa neighbourhoods an ever-evolving art piece cut short by the mysterious death of the artist who created them.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The public art of Escadaria Selarón

paragraphs.text:
This should not be missed: 215 steps linking the neighbourhoods of Lapa and Santa Teresa, covered with shards of tiles in blue, green and yellow the colours of the Brazilian flag and punctuated by red and white tiles and mirrors.

A stunning work of outsider art by the Chilean-born artist Jorge Selarón, they have become an emblem of Rio. Selarón arrived here penniless in the early 1980s and made a living through his paintings. But he soon became obsessed by a side-project, begun in 1990 the creation of his stairs. Sent to him by tourists who fell in love with the work, scavenged, or made by the artist, the tiles of the Escadaria Selarón now form part of an iconic tourist attraction, often compared to the mosaic works of Gaudí in Barcelona.

In 2013, Selarón was found dead on the steps, at the age of 65, thus bringing an end to his project, which he called a “tribute to the Brazilian people”.

Escadaria Selarón
Rua Joaquim Silva
Santa Teresa
Rio de Janeiro 20241-120

www.rio.rj.gov.br/web/guest/exibeconteudo?id=4355237

content.title: Casa Beleza: the former home of the governor

introduction.small: A picturesque villa of incredible charm, for full immersion in the authentic and historic Santa Teresa district.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Casa Beleza: the former home of the governor

paragraphs.text:
In the hills of Santa Teresa, the ‘Montmartre' of Rio with its protean villas, this guesthouse, built in 1930s Spanish style and featuring a unique turret, is owned by a Franco-Indo-Canadian-Anglo-Brazilian family headed by Antoine Olivier. Paradise set on a hill, this former home of the governor of Rio, Nilo Batista will seduce you with its 1,700-square-metre park, a refuge for monkeys, hummingbirds, and toucans. You will enjoy occupying one of the three rooms in the separate wing of the house, overlooking the pool and decorated with local elements they could not be more romantic.

Special features of the house include a bungalow with private terrace and hammock in a garden that you access via a staircase, and a 40-square-metre villa with two balconies, a rooftop terrace, a bedroom, and a lounge, ideal for a family. Note that the establishment supports eco-responsibility and finances solidarity projects and a reforestation programmed in the region.

Casa Beleza
Rua Laurinda Santos Lôbo, 311
Santa Teresa
Rio de Janeiro 20240-270

+55 (0)21 2224 7403

https://www.casabeleza.com/home-english

Rooms: from 330 BRL

content.title: The Pão de Açúcar: a postcard in granite

introduction.small: Sugarloaf Mountain is a natural wonder accessible by a scenic cable-car ride with vertiginous views.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Pão de Açúcar: a postcard in granite

paragraphs.text:
A major landmark on Rio postcards, Sugarloaf Mountain which got its name from the shape of the sugar blocks transported during the time of the sugarcane trade is 396 meters high.

This huge block of granite at the entrance to Guanabara Bay is accessed by cable car. Built in 1912 it was then only the third cable car in the world this vehicle connects the base of Morro da Babilônia favela to the top of Morro da Urca, over 200 meters high. The next leg is done in a second, newly renovated cable car, which offers panoramic views of Rio and brings you, 700 meters later, to the famous peak of Sugarloaf.

Climbers and the more adventurous will want to go from Morro da Babilônia to Sugarloaf by foot (which takes about eight hours).

Pão de Açúcar
Avenida Pasteur, 520
Urca
Rio de Janeiro 22290-240

https://www.bondinho.com.br/en/home/

content.title: Ilha de Paquetá: the mysterious island

introduction.small: Closed to car traffic, this is a paradise of rare flora and fauna, with colonial architecture adding to its charm.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ilha de Paquetá: the mysterious island

paragraphs.text:
Accessible only by boat there are ferries from the port of Rio, Praça XV de Novembro the island of Paquetá, in the centre of the Guanabara Bay, is a favourite one-night romantic getaway for couples.

It also attracts masses of Cariocas for weekend-long vacations. Formerly the territory of the indigenous Tamoio people, the island, discovered by the French in the mid-16th century, was finally taken over by the Portuguese, who divided it into two parcels. Charming for its small colonial houses and buildings, the island and its 3,000 inhabitants enjoy a car-free environment the only way to get around is on foot or by horse or bike.

When doing so, you will discover that the place is home to towering palms and twenty rare species of baobabs, found only in Brazil. The island's beautiful beaches are great places to take in a sunset, or to dine in small fresh-fish restaurants, where you can dance samba all night long.

www.ilhadepaqueta.com.br

content.title: Rodrigo de Freitas Lagoon: one of the world's most beautiful

introduction.small: Another postcard landscape, not as well known, dedicated to sport and partying.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rodrigo de Freitas Lagoon: one of the world's most beautiful

paragraphs.text:
Located in the southern zone of Rio, surrounded by mountains, modern buildings and villas, and tropical forests and beaches, Rodrigo de Freitas Lagoon is another Rio jewel.

A blue lagoon fed by salt water, it is home to many wealthy Cariocas and multiple sporting activities. The mere sight of the lake is enough to make you relax, but the bicycling opportunities are superb, including racing around the 7.2 km lakeshore path. Others prefer pedal boating on plastic swans, rowing, or water skiing, while the more adventurous take helicopters to see the magical view from the top of Parque da Catacumba. At Christmas, trees are placed in the centre of the lake, attracting thousands of tourists.

There are many great restaurants and kiosks where you can have a drink, eat dinner, or listen to live music.

Lagoa Rodrigo de Freitas lagoon
Avenida Epitácio Pessoa
Rio de Janeiro 22471-001

content.title: Maracanã: the mythical stadium of Rio

introduction.small: A temple of world football and international music.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Maracanã: the mythical stadium of Rio

paragraphs.text:
The EstádioJornalistaMárioFilho, better known under the name ‘Maracanã', is an integral part of Rio's sporting heritage. Built in two years, the oval-shaped stadium opened in 1950, and its 200,000 capacity makes it Brazil's biggest stadium. During the FIFA World Cup that year, Rio lost to neighbouring Uruguay in the final, a global event and a national tragedy.

Sixty-four years later, and after many football stars had graced the stadium Pelé, Zico, and Ronaldo among them-Brazil lost to Germany, who went on to beat the Argentinians in the final of the last World Cup, in 2014. A match between Flamengo and Fluminense play here, and the stadium has hosted giant rock and pop concerts.

Maracanã Estádio
Rua Professor Eurico Rabelo
Rio de Janeiro 20271-130

+55 (0)21 2568 9962

www.maracana.com

content.title: Vista Chinesa: an atypical and unique panoramic view

introduction.small: In the heart of Tijuca Forest, a Chinese-style pagoda opens onto heavenly views.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vista Chinesa: an atypical and unique panoramic view

paragraphs.text:
The largest urban forest in the world and just minutes from downtown Rio, the Tijuca Forest is 3,200 hectares in size.

Through its trails and winding roads, the lush vegetation hides sumptuous waterfalls (the cascada da gruta and the cascada dos macacos ), where Cariocas come to decompress and take in the stunning views, including those from the Vista Chinesa.This Chinese-style pagoda was created in the early 19th century as homage to planters from Macau (a Portuguese trading post at the time), who tried to establish tea plantations in Brazil. The project ended in failure, as coffee production won out.

While the monument itself is not memorable, the gazebo offers gorgeous views of the Zona Sul and the splendours of the city, including Christ the Redeemer and Sugarloaf.

Vista Chinesa
Parque Nacional Tijuca
Estrada da Vista Chinesa, 1294
Alto do Boa Vista
Rio de Janeiro

+55 (0)21 2492 2253

content.title: Pedra Bonita mountain: athletic paradise

introduction.small: More discreet than Sugarloaf, Pedra Bonita is the best spot to practice climbing and flying.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pedra Bonita mountain: athletic paradise

paragraphs.text:
With a summit at 696 meters, the Pedra Bonita is one of the hidden treasures of Rio. Between São Conrado and Barra da Tijuca, 30 minutes from the beaches of Copacabana, this amazing mountain in the Tijuca natural park offers an unforgettable experience in nature.

Between the hiking trails (most between 18-20 kilometres) from the heart of the largest urban forest in the world and those leading to the summit of granite, the views look out onto the Zina Sul, Sugarloaf, and Christ the Redeemer. Popular activities practiced here are climbing, paragliding, and hang-gliding from Estrada das Canoas, the main point of departure for flights lasting 10-20 minutes.

A relaxing spot to get away from the crowds of Copacabana and Ipanema, or to push yourself to the max…

La Pedra Bonita
Estrada da Cascatinha
Parque Nacional Tijuca
Rio de Janeiro 20531-590

content.title: Café Lamas : authentic Brazilian cuisine

introduction.small: In the district of Flamengo, this is a legendary address among Cariocas, at the crossroads of several generations.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Café Lamas : authentic Brazilian cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Rio's oldest restaurant, Café Lamas is a must. It is not much to look at from the outside, but the place remains etched in the memory of an older generation for having been the headquarters of the Communist Party, as well as a hangout for artists, journalists, writers, and night owls. Every luminary in Brazil has dined here.

In existence for 140 years, the Café Lamas is still a place of celebration and excitement. The servers still wear bowties and the food is much the same today as always: Brazilian cuisine extolling the virtues of meat. The garlic steak is legendary, as is the Osvaldo Aranha filet mignon, a tribute to the politician of the same name, who loved it.

Regulars also order the cebolas fritas (fried onions) and batata Portuguesa (Portuguese potato). It stays open late: you can stay and chat until three in the morning.

Café Lamas
Rua Marquês de Abrantes, 18a
Flamengo
Rio de Janeiro 2221-080

+55 (0)21 2556 0799

www.cafelamas.com.br

Menu: around 95 BRL
